Your incoming_channel & outgoing_channel are the same as 
incominglink2_inn=
um & outgoinglink2_outnum. The underlying concept is 
that links must now c=
arry "from" & "to" information. Central to your 
selected approach is the i=
mpact to the balance of the code and genome 
definition. The application of=
 an activation function which requires 
more than one-input/one-output may =
be addressed by setting the max 
allowed inputs/outputs for a given node, w=
here a mutate add link 
requires the additional specification of which uniq=
ue input/output. 
Maintaining the current functionality is also accomplishe=
d by setting 
the max allowed unique input/output to one.

Andy Carl

>
> Another approach is to have channel IDs. It depends on the 
activation =

> al=
l links to the channel IDs. Let me show you what I mean. We have 
> this no=
de, with 3 connections incoming and 2 outgoing.

s (u,v) =3D f(x,y) type. Given the 
activation

=3D=3D 0

ion is done on per channel basis. Then the results from 
the 
> incoming ch=
annels are fed in the (x, y) and the results from the 
> activation functio=
n are fed in the outgoing channels (0 and 1) - (u 
> and v).

strate the flexibility of this method, let me show what

add an incoming connection. The node will have a 
> reassign_channels() met=
hod:

> incoming[1]->l=
ink

> incoming[2]->link
> incoming_channel[2=
] =3D=3D 1

>

ose we have a mutation that changes the activation function 
> to a y=3Df(x=
) type. reassign_channels() takes this into account and 
we 
> end up with:=

> incoming[1]->link
=

> incoming[2]->link
> incoming_channel[2] =
=3D=3D 0

> 
> outgoing[0=
]->link

> outgoing[1]->link
> outgoing_chann=
el[1] =3D=3D 0
> 
> - all in the same channel.
>

r, I don't know. :)

> > > > > to 
> > > > > >=
 perform a rotation. As Jason's posts imply (and Peter 
> > stated), 
> > >=

> > > per=
form 
> > > > > > rotations.  And, in fact, they do.  When I play with God =

> Mode 
> > > in 
> > > > > > genetic art I often find weights that when a=
djusted 
rotate 
> a 
> > > part 
> > > > > of 
> > > > > > the image.  Tha=
t is not that unusual (although perhaps 
not 
> as 
> > > > usual 
> > > > =
> > as we'd like either).
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > However, that kind of ro=
tation actually *isn't* the type 
we 
> > > > really 
> > > > > > need.  Th=
e issue is not that a particular shape should be 
> > > > possible 
> > > >=
 > to 
> > > > > > rotate some arbitrary angle by changing some weights. 
>=
 Recall 
> > > that 
> > > > > > CPPNs work by laying out coordinate frames=
 within which 
> > higher 
> > > > > > strucutres are situated.  To create =
a symmetric 
coordinate 
> > > frame 
> > > > > means
> > > > > > creating =
a gradient with *two* sides, both the opposite 
of 
> > each 
> > > > > > o=
ther.  That is, symmetry is not created by flipping a 
> > gradient 
> > > =
> > from 
> > > > > > one side to the other, but rather by having both side=
s at 
> the 
> > > > same 
> > > > > > time.
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > There=
fore, a rotational coordinate frame should actually 
> > > contain 
> > > >=
 > > something akin to a sinusoidal gradient that spreads 
around 
> a 
> >=
 > > > circle 
> > > > > > rather than along a line. Then, structures situa=
ted 
within 
> > its 
> > > > > > coordinate frame would repeat in a rotate=
d regular 
pattern, 
> > > like 
> > > > > > petals on a flower (that way y=
ou get rotatonal 
> invariance).  
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > Thus what we re=
ally want is to be able to feed in a 
regular 
> > 2D 
> > > > > > coordina=
te frame and output another coordinate frame that 
> is 
> > a 
> > > > sin=
e 
> > > > > > wave around a circle in 2D as well.  In other words:
> > > >=
 > > 
> > > > > > f(x,y)=3Da point in this circular petal-like gradient
> >=
 > > > > 
> > > > > > Thus we only need to define a function like that and =
make 
> it 
> > an 
> > > > > > activation function that takes two distinct=
 inputs.
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > However, the problem does remain of where=
 to control the 
> > period 
> > > > of 
> > > > > > repetition around the =
circle.
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > Actually, thinking of it now, what we real=
ly want is NOT 
> what 
> > I 
> > > > > just 
> > > > > > said but rather =
something a bit different that would 
solve 
> > the 
> > > > > > problem I=
 just posed: What we want is a function f(x,y) 
> that 
> > > > > produces =

> > > > > > a gradient that starts at 0 on e.g. the x axis and then 
> > >=
 increases 
> > > > > up 
> > > > > > to 1 as you rotate around the origin =
to 360 degrees.
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > That way, you have a true circular=
/polar coordinate 
> system.  
> > > Then 
> > > > > you 
> > > > > > can s=
imply run its output into a sine wave, and you get 
the 
> > > > > > repeti=
tion around the circle that I describe above.  Then 
> the 
> > > > > > fre=
quency of repetition is controlled very easily by 
> varying 
> > > the 
> =
> > > > > weight leaving the polar function and entering the sine 
> wave, =

> > > > just 
> > > > > > as in any normal CPPN!
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > =
So I guess my conclusion is we just need a function that 
> > > converts 
>=

> its =

> > > > output 
> > > > > > into a periodic activation function will give =
your nice 
> > > > rotational 
> > > > > > repetition, which in a neural su=
bstrate is rotational 
> > > invariance!

> > > > > > Hmm...so =

the base-
level 
> x 
> > > and

ases will actually yield nice localized

effects as well).
